statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: Oregon State 65, Oregon 62
article.story: CORVALLIS, Ore. (AP) -- Injured Oregon State point guard Lamar Hurd made it to the floor for his final game at Gill Coliseum on Saturday, just long enough to get in the game to make his farewell appearance. Symbolically added to the starting lineup, the senior was substituted off the floor to a standing ovation after the opening tip. Then he sat and watched his teammates put up an energetic and inspired 65-62 win over Oregon in the Civil War. Sasa Cuic had 21 points to lead the Beavers, who finished the regular season in ninth place in the Pac-10 and will play eighth-place Arizona State in the conference tournament Wednesday in Los Angeles. The Ducks, who got 20 points from Chamberlain Oguchi, finished seventh and play 10th-seed Washington State. The gesture for Hurd was orchestrated by Beaver coach Jay John, whose team had lost 11 of 13 games since the four-year starter and captain went down with a groin injury. "I've got to give a lot of credit to (Oregon coach) Ernie Kent on that," John said. "He was really receptive to that, and the officials were also. ... I genuinely applaud that and appreciate it for Lamar." Marcel Jones added 10 points and six rebounds and Kyle Jeffers had eight points, eight rebounds, four steals and three blocks for the Beavers (12-17, 5-13). Oregon State seemed to just want the game more. They brought the energy and motivation the Ducks were missing. The Beavers led 33-28 after a 7-2 run, and then 37-30 at the half. "It was a a very poor effort for us," Oguchi said. "They came out and treated it like it was the Civil War. We treated it like it was just another game." Malik Hairston added 11 points and seven rebounds for Oregon (13-17, 7-11). Duck point guard Aaron Brooks came into the game averaging 17 points, 4.7 assists and no turnovers in his last three games, but had an off night, with five points, three assists and three turnovers, sitting most of the second half in favor of backup Brandon Lincoln. Oregon State was also without senior Nick DeWitz, whose season ended when he separated his shoulder last week against USC. The Ducks briefly took a 50-49 lead on Maarty Leunen's dunk at 7:21 in the second half, but Cuic made back-to-back 3s for Oregon State. Leunen countered with a 3-pointer at 1:19 to get within 61-60. But, in a lucky break for the Beavers, Cuic tapped a Stephens miss hard against the top part of the backboard. Somehow the ball ricocheted down into the hoop, extending Oregon State's lead to three. Leunen hit two free throws to get the Ducks within one again, but Stephens missed two free throws for the Beavers, and Oguchi airballed a 3-point attempt at the buzzer. "I thought, to Oregon State's credit, they looked like a different basketball team than they've looked on tape," Kent said. "The team I saw play USC, UCLA, Washington -- they played much better basketball, much headier basketball." Chris Stephens hit his 179th career 3-pointer, tying Deaundra Tanner (1997-01) for first place in Oregon State history. Cuic scored over 20 points for the sixth time in his last 10 games. "It feels great for us, just a lot of confidence for the next game," he said. "And it was especially great for the fans and seniors going out winning the Civil War at Gill for these guys. There's no better way to go out." Cuic, a sophomore from Rijeka, Croatia, is the Beavers' top scorer, averaging 13.6 points. After the game he was in a celebrating mood. "There's a party at our house tonight," he said.
